lexicon_requests.reason: Rare superscription - only here and Ps 119:171, need semantic distinction from other praise terms
Rare power term in v.6 - limited biblical usage, need precise meaning
Job language borrowed for divine incomprehensibility - theological significance
Liquid metaphor for speech in v.7 - unique praise vocabulary
Intensive praise form in v.3 - morphological and semantic analysis needed
Meditation/recitation verb in v.5 - cultic vs personal dimension
Awesome deeds vocabulary - theological weight of 'nora' root
Part of triple glory accumulation - distinct from kevod and hod?
Hopeful waiting in v.15 - semantic range of expectation
Ambiguous in v.16 - divine favor or creatures' desire?
Dominion term in Ugaritic parallel - ANE royal vocabulary
Bent over ones in v.14 - specific vulnerability imagery

concordance_requests.purpose: Eternal kingship formulas and Ugaritic parallels
Eternity formula usage - appears twice in opening verses

figurative_requests.reason: Pour forth praise - vivid liquid metaphor for speech overflow | Vehicle: pour forth | Related terms: pour, pours, pouring, gush, gushes, gushing, flow, flows, flowing
Fathoming divine greatness - epistemological impossibility imagery | Vehicle: fathom | Related terms: search, searching, probe, probing, investigate, investigation
Supporting the falling - physical divine intervention imagery | Vehicle: support | Related terms: supports, supporting, uphold, upholds, upholding, sustain, sustains, sustaining
Raising the bent - restoration of vulnerable imagery | Vehicle: raise up | Related terms: raise, raises, raising, lift, lifts, lifting, straighten, straightens
Eyes waiting hopefully - expectant gaze as universal dependence | Vehicle: wait hopefully | Related terms: wait, waiting, hope, hoping, expect, expecting, look, looking
Opening divine hand - generosity gesture imagery | Vehicle: open hand | Related terms: open, opens, opening, extend, extends, extending

commentary_requests.reason: Rare tehillah superscription - how do commentators explain its uniqueness and relationship to standard praise terminology?
Daily blessing vow - traditional interpretation of perpetual praise obligation and spiritual discipline
Divine incomprehensibility - classical understanding of 'no searching' and relationship to Job parallels
Intergenerational praise - how commentators interpret transmission of divine knowledge across generations
Triple glory accumulation - traditional parsing of hadar/kevod/hod distinctions and poetic intensification
Ketiv/qere variation - how commentators handle textual uncertainty and awesome deeds language
Liquid praise metaphor - classical interpretation of 'pour forth' and relationship between memory and celebration
Exodus 34 quotation - why insert systematic theology here and how it functions as psalm's pivot
Universal divine goodness - traditional reconciliation with particular divine judgment themes
Creation vs faithful distinction - how commentators explain different praise verbs for different communities
Royal vocabulary intensification - classical understanding of divine kingship and speech act emphasis
Missionary dimension - traditional interpretation of human proclamation role and person shift
Ugaritic parallel and LXX addition - how classical commentators handle eternal kingship formula
Cosmic to personal shift - traditional understanding of divine kingship through concrete care
Universal dependence imagery - classical interpretation of eye metaphor and divine timing
Divine generosity - traditional understanding of open hand gesture and satisfaction language
Character summary - how commentators distinguish divine ways vs works and universal righteousness
Qualified universalism - traditional interpretation of 'in truth' condition and divine nearness
Sequential divine response - classical understanding of desire-to-deliverance progression and fear-reverence
Moral dualism - how commentators reconcile protection/destruction with universal mercy theme
Inclusio completion - traditional understanding of individual-to-cosmic praise trajectory and 'all flesh' terminology

ugaritic_parallels.analysis: This shared formula for celebrating divine kingship demonstrates a common liturgical and royal vocab...

macro_questions: What is the theological significance of the missing nun verse in the acrostic, and how do ancient versions handle this gap?
How does the sevenfold use of 'kol' (all/every) function as a literary and theological device throughout the psalm?
What is the relationship between the divine character formula in v. 8 and Exodus 34:6-7, and how does this psalm expand or modify that tradition?
How does the Ugaritic parallel in vv. 11-13 illuminate the psalm's appropriation and transformation of Ancient Near Eastern royal ideology?
What is the significance of the intergenerational motif (dor le-dor) for understanding the psalm's theology of covenant continuity?
How does the alternation between divine transcendence (greatness, majesty) and immanence (care, provision) function structurally and theologically?
What is the liturgical function of the movement from individual vow to cosmic participation, and how does this relate to temple worship practices?
How do the specific images of divine care (supporting the falling, feeding the hungry, protecting the righteous) relate to Ancient Near Eastern royal ideology and social justice themes?
What is the relationship between divine kingship and divine judgment in vv. 19-20, and how does this compare to other royal psalms?
micro_questions: Why does the psalm use the rare superscription 'תְּהִלָּה' only here and Psalm 119:171?
What is the significance of the missing nun verse in the acrostic - textual accident or intentional theological statement?
How does the triple accumulation 'הֲדַר כְּבוֹד הוֹדֶךָ' function - are these distinct attributes or poetic intensification?
Why does the LXX add an entire extra verse (13a) about divine faithfulness?
How do we reconcile universal divine mercy (v.9) with universal destruction of the wicked (v.20)?
What motivates the dramatic shift from cosmic kingship language (vv.11-13) to concrete care imagery (vv.14-16)?
Why does the psalm borrow Job's 'אֵין חֵקֶר' language for divine incomprehensibility?
What is the theological significance of different praise verbs for creation (thank) versus faithful ones (bless) in verse 10?
How does 'כׇל־בָּשָׂר' (all flesh) in the conclusion relate to the cosmic scope established earlier?
Why integrate the exact Exodus 34:6-7 formula rather than creating original praise language?
